question.title: IllegalArgumentException or NullPointerException for a null parameter?
question.body: I have a simple setter method for a property and null is not appropriate for this particular property. I have always been torn in this situation: should I throw an IllegalArgumentException, or a NullPointerException? From the javadocs, both seem appropriate. Is there some kind of an understood standard? Or is this just one of those things that you should do whatever you prefer and both are really correct?

answers.body:
Some collections assume that null is rejected using NullPointerException rather than IllegalArgumentException. For example, if you compare a set containing null to a set that rejects null, the first set will call containsAll on the other and catch its NullPointerException -- but not IllegalArgumentException. (I'm looking at the implementation of AbstractSet.equals.)

You could reasonably argue that using unchecked exceptions in this way is an antipattern, that comparing collections that contain null to collections that can't contain null is a likely bug that really should produce an exception, or that putting null in a collection at all is a bad idea. Nevertheless, unless you're willing to say that equals should throw an exception in such a case, you're stuck remembering that NullPointerException is required in certain circumstances but not in others. ("IAE before NPE except after 'c'...")

Somewhat similarly, build tools or the runtime may insert null checks automatically. Notably, Kotlin's compiler does this when passing a possibly null value to a Java API. And when a check fails, the result is a NullPointerException. In addition, we might see the same automatic NullPointerException thrown for a potential future feature in Java itself. So, to give consistent behavior to any Kotlin users and potentially someday Java users, you'd need to use NullPointerException.
